nodes.title: AutoAgents: A Framework for Automatic Agent Generation
nodes.abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have enabled remarkable advances in automated task-solving with multi-agent systems. However, most existing LLM-based multi-agent approaches rely on predefined agents to handle simple tasks, limiting the adaptability of multi-agent collaboration to different scenarios. Therefore, we introduce AutoAgents, an innovative framework that adaptively generates and coordinates multiple specialized agents to build an AI team according to different tasks. Specifically, AutoAgents couples the relationship between tasks and roles by dynamically generating multiple required agents based on task content and planning solutions for the current task based on the generated expert agents. Multiple specialized agents collaborate with each other to efficiently accomplish tasks. Concurrently, an observer role is incorporated into the framework to reflect on the designated plans and agents' responses and improve upon them. Our experiments on various benchmarks demonstrate that AutoAgents generates more coherent and accurate solutions than the existing multi-agent methods. This underscores the significance of assigning different roles to different tasks and of team cooperation, offering new perspectives for tackling complex tasks. The repository of this project is available at https://github.com/Link-AGI/AutoAgents.
nodes.display_name: AutoAgents: A Framework for Automatic Agent Generation
nodes.id: AutoAgents: A Framework for Automatic Agent Generation

nodes.name: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
nodes.display_name: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
nodes.id: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology

nodes.name: AutoAgents
nodes.description: An innovative framework that adaptively generates and coordinates multiple specialized agents to build an AI team according to different tasks, dynamically generating required agents based on task content and planning solutions.

nodes.name: Multi-agent systems
nodes.description: Systems where multiple agents collaborate to solve tasks, but existing approaches rely on predefined agents limiting adaptability to different scenarios.

nodes.name: LLM-based multi-agent approaches
nodes.description: Existing approaches that use large language models for automated task-solving but rely on predefined agents, limiting adaptability to different scenarios.

nodes.name: Observer role
nodes.description: A role incorporated into the AutoAgents framework that reflects on designated plans and agents' responses to improve upon them.

nodes.name: https://github.com/Link-AGI/AutoAgents
nodes.description: The repository containing the implementation and resources for the AutoAgents framework project.

nodes.title: From Local to Global: A GraphRAG Approach to Query-Focused Summarization
nodes.abstract: The use of retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) to retrieve relevant information from an external knowledge source enables large language models (LLMs) to answer questions over private and/or previously unseen document collections. However, RAG fails on global questions directed at an entire text corpus, such as "What are the main themes in the dataset?", since this is inherently a query-focused summarization (QFS) task, rather than an explicit retrieval task. Prior QFS methods, meanwhile, do not scale to the quantities of text indexed by typical RAG systems. To combine the strengths of these contrasting methods, we propose GraphRAG, a graph-based approach to question answering over private text corpora that scales with both the generality of user questions and the quantity of source text. Our approach uses an LLM to build a graph index in two stages: first, to derive an entity knowledge graph from the source documents, then to pre-generate community summaries for all groups of closely related entities. Given a question, each community summary is used to generate a partial response, before all partial responses are again summarized in a final response to the user. For a class of global sensemaking questions over datasets in the 1 million token range, we show that GraphRAG leads to substantial improvements over a conventional RAG baseline for both the comprehensiveness and diversity of generated answers.
nodes.display_name: From Local to Global: A GraphRAG Approach to Query-Focused Summarization
nodes.id: From Local to Global: A GraphRAG Approach to Query-Focused Summarization

nodes.name: GraphRAG
nodes.description: A graph-based approach to question answering over private text corpora that combines retrieval-augmented generation and query-focused summarization, using a two-stage graph index construction with LLMs.

nodes.name: RAG
nodes.description: Retrieval-augmented generation method that retrieves relevant information from external knowledge sources to enable LLMs to answer questions over private document collections.

nodes.name: QFS
nodes.description: Query-focused summarization methods that address global questions directed at entire text corpora but do not scale to large quantities of text.

nodes.name: LLMs
nodes.description: Large language models used to build the graph index in GraphRAG through entity knowledge graph derivation and community summary generation.

nodes.name: Entity Knowledge Graph
nodes.description: First stage of GraphRAG's graph index construction where an LLM derives a knowledge graph from source documents by extracting entities and their relationships.

nodes.name: Community Summaries
nodes.description: Second stage of GraphRAG where pre-generated summaries are created for groups of closely related entities in the knowledge graph, used to generate partial responses to questions.

nodes.name: Global Sensemaking Questions
nodes.description: Class of questions directed at entire text corpora, such as identifying main themes, which conventional RAG fails to address effectively.

nodes.title: HiRAG: Retrieval-Augmented Generation with Hierarchical Knowledge
nodes.abstract:
Graph-based Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) methods have significantly enhanced the performance of large language models (LLMs) in domain-specific tasks. However, existing RAG methods do not adequately utilize the naturally inherent hierarchical knowledge in human cognition, which limits the capabilities of RAG systems. In this paper, we introduce a new RAG approach, called HiRAG, which utilizes hierarchical knowledge to enhance the semantic understanding and structure capturing capabilities of RAG systems in the indexing and retrieval processes. Our extensive experiments demonstrate that HiRAG achieves significant performance improvements over the state-of-the-art baseline methods.1

Footnote 1: https://github.com/hhy-huang/HiRAG
nodes.display_name: HiRAG: Retrieval-Augmented Generation with Hierarchical Knowledge
nodes.id: HiRAG: Retrieval-Augmented Generation with Hierarchical Knowledge

nodes.name: The Chinese University of Hong Kong

nodes.id: The Chinese University of Hong Kong

nodes.name: HiRAG
nodes.description: A new Retrieval-Augmented Generation approach that utilizes hierarchical knowledge to enhance semantic understanding and structure capturing capabilities in the indexing and retrieval processes.

nodes.name: Hierarchical Knowledge
nodes.description: The naturally inherent hierarchical knowledge in human cognition that existing RAG methods do not adequately utilize, which HiRAG leverages to improve performance.

nodes.name: Graph-based RAG
nodes.description: Existing Retrieval-Augmented Generation methods that have enhanced LLM performance but lack hierarchical knowledge utilization, serving as the baseline that HiRAG improves upon.

nodes.name: Semantic Understanding
nodes.description: The capability of understanding meaning and context that HiRAG enhances through hierarchical knowledge utilization in RAG systems.

nodes.name: https://github.com/hhy-huang/HiRAG
nodes.description: The GitHub repository containing the implementation and resources for the HiRAG framework.

nodes.title: KnowledgeHub: An End-to-End Tool for Assisted Scientific Discovery
nodes.abstract: This paper describes the KnowledgeHub tool, a scientific literature Information Extraction (IE) and Question Answering (QA) pipeline. This is achieved by supporting the ingestion of PDF documents that are converted to text and structured representations. An ontology can then be constructed where a user defines the types of entities and relationships they want to capture. A browser-based annotation tool enables annotating the contents of the PDF documents according to the ontology. Named Entity Recognition (NER) and Relation Classification (RC) models can be trained on the resulting annotations and can be used to annotate the unannotated portion of the documents. A knowledge graph is constructed from these entity and relation triples which can be queried to obtain insights from the data. Furthermore, we integrate a suite of Large Language Models (LLMs) that can be used for QA and summarisation that is grounded in the included documents via a retrieval component. KnowledgeHub is a unique tool that supports annotation, IE and QA, which gives the user full insight into the knowledge discovery pipeline.
nodes.display_name: KnowledgeHub: An End-to-End Tool for Assisted Scientific Discovery
nodes.id: KnowledgeHub: An End-to-End Tool for Assisted Scientific Discovery

nodes.name: KnowledgeHub
nodes.description: A scientific literature Information Extraction and Question Answering pipeline that supports PDF ingestion, annotation, entity recognition, relation classification, and knowledge graph construction with integrated LLM capabilities.

nodes.name: Named Entity Recognition
nodes.description: A method used within KnowledgeHub to identify and classify named entities in scientific documents based on user-defined ontologies and trained models.

nodes.name: Relation Classification
nodes.description: A method employed by KnowledgeHub to classify relationships between identified entities in scientific literature, trained on annotated data.

nodes.name: Knowledge Graph
nodes.description: A structured representation constructed from entity and relation triples extracted by KnowledgeHub, enabling querying and insights from scientific documents.

nodes.name: Large Language Models
nodes.description: AI models integrated into KnowledgeHub for Question Answering and summarization tasks, grounded in document content through retrieval mechanisms.

nodes.name: Annotation Tool
nodes.description: A browser-based component of KnowledgeHub that enables users to annotate PDF documents according to custom ontologies for entity and relationship extraction.

nodes.title: Nougat: Neural Optical Understanding for Academic Documents
nodes.abstract: Scientific knowledge is predominantly stored in books and scientific journals, often in the form of PDFs. However, the PDF format leads to a loss of semantic information, particularly for mathematical expressions. We propose Nougat (Neural Optical Understanding for Academic Dcuments), a Visual Transformer model that performs an Optical Character Recognition (OCR) task for processing scientific documents into a markup language, and demonstrate the effectiveness of our model on a new dataset of scientific documents. The proposed approach offers a promising solution to enhance the accessibility of scientific knowledge in the digital age, by bridging the gap between human-readable documents and machine-readable text. We release the models and code to accelerate future work on scientific text recognition.
nodes.display_name: Nougat: Neural Optical Understanding for Academic Documents
nodes.id: Nougat: Neural Optical Understanding for Academic Documents

nodes.name: Nougat
nodes.description: Neural Optical Understanding for Academic Documents, a Visual Transformer model that performs OCR for scientific documents to convert them into markup language, specifically designed to handle mathematical expressions in PDFs.

nodes.name: Scientific PDFs
nodes.description: Scientific documents stored in PDF format that lose semantic information, particularly for mathematical expressions, creating accessibility issues for machine processing.

nodes.name: Mathematical expressions
nodes.description: Specific content in scientific documents that suffers from semantic information loss when stored in PDF format, making them difficult for machines to process accurately.

nodes.name: Markup language
nodes.description: Machine-readable text format that Nougat converts scientific PDFs into, preserving semantic information and enhancing accessibility.

nodes.name: Visual Transformer model
nodes.description: The neural architecture used by Nougat to perform optical character recognition on scientific documents, enabling the conversion from PDF to markup language.

nodes.name: New dataset of scientific documents
nodes.description: A newly created dataset used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the Nougat model in processing scientific documents into machine-readable markup language.

nodes.title: Zep: A Temporal Knowledge Graph Architecture for Agent Memory
nodes.abstract: We introduce Zep, a novel memory layer service for AI agents that outperforms the current state-of-the-art system, MemGPT, in the Deep Memory Retrieval (DMR) benchmark. Additionally, Zep excels in more comprehensive and challenging evaluations than DMR that better reflect real-world enterprise use cases. While existing retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) frameworks for large language model (LLM)-based agents are limited to static document retrieval, enterprise applications demand dynamic knowledge integration from diverse sources including ongoing conversations and business data. Zep addresses this fundamental limitation through its core component Graphiti--a temporally-aware knowledge graph engine that dynamically synthesizes both unstructured conversational data and structured business data while maintaining historical relationships. In the DMR benchmark, which the MemGPT team established as their primary evaluation metric, Zep demonstrates superior performance (94.8% vs 93.4%). Beyond DMR, Zep's capabilities are further validated through the more challenging LongMemEval benchmark, which better reflects enterprise use cases through complex temporal reasoning tasks. In this evaluation, Zep achieves substantial results with accuracy improvements of up to 18.5% while simultaneously reducing response latency by 90% compared to baseline implementations. These results are particularly pronounced in enterprise-critical tasks such as cross-session information synthesis and long-term context maintenance, demonstrating Zep's effectiveness for deployment in real-world applications.
nodes.display_name: Zep: A Temporal Knowledge Graph Architecture for Agent Memory
nodes.id: Zep: A Temporal Knowledge Graph Architecture for Agent Memory

nodes.name: Zep
nodes.description: A novel memory layer service for AI agents that outperforms MemGPT in the DMR benchmark and excels in enterprise use cases through dynamic knowledge integration from diverse sources including conversations and business data.

nodes.name: Graphiti
nodes.description: The core component of Zep, a temporally-aware knowledge graph engine that dynamically synthesizes both unstructured conversational data and structured business data while maintaining historical relationships.

nodes.name: MemGPT
nodes.description: The current state-of-the-art system that Zep outperforms in the Deep Memory Retrieval (DMR) benchmark, serving as the primary comparison baseline.

nodes.name: Deep Memory Retrieval (DMR) benchmark
nodes.description: The primary evaluation metric established by the MemGPT team where Zep demonstrates superior performance (94.8% vs 93.4%) compared to MemGPT.

nodes.name: LongMemEval benchmark
nodes.description: A more challenging evaluation benchmark that better reflects enterprise use cases through complex temporal reasoning tasks, where Zep achieves substantial accuracy improvements of up to 18.5%.

nodes.name: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) frameworks
nodes.description: Existing frameworks for LLM-based agents that are limited to static document retrieval, which Zep addresses through dynamic knowledge integration capabilities.
